p: Our results showed that the specific residues in BgV NS4A, NS4B and NS5 identified in vitro were directly involved in increased infectivity and pathogenesis in vivo. This was revealed by comparing data from prototype-injected mice with mutant-injected mice (BgV C-CG vs BgV T-AT, and BgV C-CG/WNV-prME vs BgV T-AT/WNV-prME). Our results also suggest that the BgV structural genes (prM and E) might be involved in BgV attenuation in vertebrates. Indeed, our results establish that while the BgV-prME proteins can facilitate infection in vertebrates, as shown by the data from WNV/BgV-prME inoculated mice, the insertion of these genes resulted in attenuated phenotypes compared to the corresponding viruses with WNV-prME. WNV/BgV-prME was significantly less virulent than WNV FLSDX when compared to studies performed under similar conditions [ 35]–CD1 mice having received a 10 4 IU IP dose of WNV FLSDX all succumb to the infection after 8 days–and both versions of BgV seemed to replicate less efficiently than their BgV/WNV-prME counterpart in mice. Taken together, these comparisons suggest that BgV attenuation may be influenced by inefficient binding and/or entering to vertebrate cells, as well as reduced replication efficiency due to the key residues identified in the non-structural viral proteins.
